job_title: Teaching Associate Professor in Boulder, CO
pros: The bureaucracy at such a large university uses such massive standardized forms and documents, that every single thing you do, you have to fill out forms, get them approved by your supervisor. Unfortunately, your supervisor can cancel anything you've planned and can pull the funding at the last minute is they see the money being better used on one of their own program.
cons: There is a lack of Diversity (only 561 black students are enrolled out or a student population of 30,000. Lack of equity: by forcing all non-TT faculty to take "at will" contract, non-TT faculty can be fired, have their contracts discontinued or not renewed with NO CAUSE and therefore no way to appeal it. It also means that if they do not renew your contract, you lose all your income, health insurance, and the rest of your benefits immediately.

review_title: CU increases workload without additional pay
job_title: Associate Teaching Professor in Boulder, CO
pros: It is beautiful in Boulder, and the students are often wonderful.
cons: The pay is comparatively terrible, and the workload has nearly doubled (from 45 students per semester to 80 for a full-time contract) with no increase whatsoever in salary (this salary range is adjusted for inflation over the years). If faculty wish to maintain work/life balance, they have little choice but to cut back  what they give to each student - this isn't fair to the students, of course, but it is simply not possible any longer to offer what we once did to our students. It is heartbreaking that CU has turned so deeply to a corporate model, with overpaid top administrators completely out of touch with what CU students need and deserve. The top administrator at CU makes more than 14 times the salary of a hard-working teacher working very closely with students who need real engagement and presence. And perhaps this is an apples to oranges equation, but the salary of the CU football coach is absurd.

review_title: Has good benefits, and work-life balance, rampant ageism, (+ overwork, not transparent)
pros: Health Benefits, beautiful campus, work-life balance can be good depending on the dept. and manager that you work for. Bus pass is free.
cons: Be careful of how involved the departments above your department are and ask questions about they are not micromanaging and have a different agenda than your supervisors. Unfortunately, ageism is a thing at CU Boulder; they can't afford people that have been there too long because of salary increases over time; watch your back as you get older (even if you think everything is okay). If they start taking away your job and automating it, or consolidating your job duties to another department, or giving you work that has nothing to do with your job (because they lay off the people that did this job) make sure to start asking questions, and start looking for another job. Although they try and tout they are into diversity, they are either overly obsessed with this and the way they hire (hiring ONLY diversity) or go the complete opposite direction and those that are diverse, seems to be a token hire, rather than really embracing diversity.

review_title: Toxic faculty, toxic leadership and toxic support staff who are shielded by HR. Stay away!
pros: The campus is beautiful and you can ride public transportation for free
cons:
At The Engineering School it’s unfortunately all about falling in line and kissing the proper rear-ends. The pay is terrible, and all the talk about work-home balance is a joke - as is all the talk about fixing the well-known culture problem. 

Time off isn’t great when you are unable to use it. Most staff are grossly underpaid and poorly managed, so they are like rats climbing upon the backs of other rats trying to backstab and credit-hog a raise into existence. You will most likely encounter supervisors who are unskilled and would be more fit as  administrative assistants. This type of "manager" will possibly have graduated from CU 30 or so years ago and may have only ever worked in education and therefore has no idea how business or the world works. 

HR will protect these types of managers and Faculty members/chairs, no matter how toxic their behavior may be - sexism, ageism, nepotism. There is no opportunity to advance and there are no career tracks. Most jobs are not state jobs, they’re known as “university staff” and not protected at all from toxic managers and restructuring which may remove your position. 

I would never suggest this place to anyone unless you are already swimming in the Boulder bubble and enjoying all the politics and headgames and also enjoy working for crumbs. I've worked in and out of higher education for almost 30 years, and I've never worked anywhere as toxic as CU Boulder. Terrible workplace, terrible managers, leadership and terrible HR which enables these people to act with impunity.

review_title: Not what the hiring manager will sell you
pros: Colorado is nice. There are some genuinely good people around trying to make this community better.
cons: You can't afford to work at CU on a CU salary as a professional staff, cost of living is just way too high and growing. There are no opportunities for advancement and no significant pay raises for staff. The financial priority is on paying faculty above-average, which means staff are (systematically according to HR policy) kept at 30-40% below the market average for similar jobs. Professional Exempt status is used to exploit unpaid overtime work. Paid leave and parental leave are actively discouraged, and if you do take the contracted time off it will negatively impact your coworkers. The benefits do not make up for an extraordinarily toxic work culture of staff exploitation by faculty and administrators. The 2022 Cultural Survey demonstrated the severe issues of discrimination and abused that are going unaddressed. If you are not a straight, white, married, non-disabled person then CU is not here to advance your life.

review_title: Wardenburg Health Center - Felt like a cog in the system within the scheme of a system that didn't care for students
job_title: Patient Access Coordinator in Boulder, CO
pros:
-401k Program was very nice
-People you work with (not leadership) are genuinely really nice and care about you
cons:
-Leadership has no idea what you really do within your job and you feel incredibly left out when they are making decisions pertaining to you
-It's obvious that the University was prioritizing profits and making sure certain departments didn't turn over in the face of a deadly pandemic, to which the University was one of the biggest culprits of outbreaks within Boulder and the state of Colorado
-Complaints, issues, etc made in respect to things like harassment, racism, etc do not make it far with leadership, and if they make it to the OIEC system, it usually results in victim blaming
-There was absolutely no way that I felt like I could be promoted or climb up in my career, it was apparent that I was just to serve my short time at Wardenburg and then work my way out of the University
-Diversity is an absolute joke - especially within leadership. The fact that we needed to hire a new Medical Director and the best finalists we chose were all white is absolutely disgusting. It's clear that this University strives to perpetuate white supremacy and refuses to acknowledge it's impact on perpetuating racism within a horribly racist institution

review_title: Don’t work for departments under Student Affairs
pros: Many learning opportunities. Beautiful campus. Good benefits.
cons:
Stress from too many responsibilities put on few workers-and constant threat that positions may be cut. 

Student Affairs leadership leads by fear rather than courage. Constantly worried we are not doing enough, changing directions at the whim of higher ups, and the entire dept was worried about losing jobs constantly or various depts being consolidated. They said they valued culture, and our well being but when you can’t be truthful or disagree without fear of losing your job or fear of being on the wrong side it creates stress and a non-trusting work environment. Also, the last few years, it seems there is a lot of reverse racism going on in top leadership and hiring practices. Cliquish. They are constantly trying to save money, so in the process, consolidation of job duties, responsibilities, and outsourcing is always at top of mind. Job stability is a myth here. As you move up the ranks, you are a moving target as you make more money yearly (incremental). Seems like they care little about connection with employees, and just care about stats and the bottom line.

review_title: If you are looking for growth this is not the place.
pros: Great benefits, you can utilize the parking garage to park your car there. Retirement fund, you put in 5% they put in 10%. You might get seasonal gear.
cons:
They require you to obtain a associates degree, or a bachelors degree. (You don’t need a degree to do this stuff). 
If you work there for more than five years you may perhaps obtain a 40 cent raise.
Soon you will be making the same money as a minimum wage job in boulder.
You will be treated with low respect and biased assumptions. 
If you have 14 years of experience you will be micromanaged daily.
This job has had a opening for a new position 7 times in 5 years. 
Uses mainly google sheets, only half the staff actually uses this.
You are required to submit time sheets that are easily modified via excel, and given no time during the work day to complete them. 
Expect countless days of working extra time without receiving O.T. Pay. 
HR is really good at turning their heads or brushing you under the carpet.
Expect to be exhausted daily for completing other employees tasks. 
During event driven over time expect to work 14-22 hour days, with maybe one 30 min break. 
During football season you may work 35 days straight. 
You are bashed for trying to have a personal life.
You will pay 720+ yearly to park your car.

job_title: Student Researcher, Computational and Semantic Linguistics, VSAP in Boulder, CO
pros: Part of the reason that this is the best job on the planet is because this is a prestigious project which allows a person interested in working in a linguistics field to gain full exposure to the research methods that underlie AI, all while getting a degree, which allows for an easier and more successful transition into work in the corporate world. It also doesn't hurt that all of the people who dedicate their time to supervise and run this project are fantastic. Last but not least, this job is so special and worthwhile because of the fact that it is a telecommuting position. Meetings usually occur only once or twice a semester for most people working in my same capacity, and are always catered. The VSAP team has always been comprised of a diverse and multi-cultural group of loyal and dedicated staff, people who aren't just co-workers, but friends.
cons: There are not many drawbacks to working for VSAP or any of Dr. Martha Palmer's linguistic projects. The University does not offer undergrad student employees with health insurance, paid vacation or really any of the traditional benefits that one looks for in a job, but this job is really so great that it makes little difference.

review_title: Obvious that staff are low priority...
pros: Beautiful campus, dedication to sustainability, nice staff members, great benefits (when you receive them), ample vacation and sick time
cons:
I didn't receive timely payment for my first day of work or the promised moving expenses detailed in my offer letter. I finally received both payments after over 30 days.  I budgeted around the fact my offer letter provided a specific day I would receive my moving expenses.  When I ask for clarity on when I would receive my payment, Business Services didn't provide me a timeline and told me to simply wait.  One representative mentioned they would send me a form to process the late payments, but they acted without urgency and sent it days later - which I'm fairly certain delayed my payment even further.  I understand there are processes that must be followed, but I was never offered an explanation on why the process took as long as it did.  This made me feel disrespected and honestly forgotten.  

It's very clear that staff are low priority. Late payments are a common occurrence as I talked more with staff and students. I have no idea how this is an acceptable and legal practice.  The institution isn't going to offer you a loan if they don't pay you - they expect you to have the savings to be able to move states and start a new job. It's evident there is a lot of privilege here - very little help for students, staff, and faculty with low income. They don't even have a food pantry on campus for the 36% of students that experience food insecurity. CU Boulder needs to do better.

review_title: Overall a great R1 employer, depending on your dept culture
pros: I've worked at CU-Boulder in one job or another (first as a grad student and now as a full time academic professional) for 9 years. The campus is beautiful, the people are overall friendly and positive, and my work (I now am in the Office of Information Technology) is fulfilling. My co-workers are fantastic people; in this regard I am lucky, because it makes me happy to come to work. It depends on the culture of the unit or department you are in; I know other people in other areas of campus where the culture is more toxic, and they're miserable. Thus, it's difficult to generalize the whole institution.
cons: Overall, it's a great place to be; lots of opportunity and change, but you have to keep an eye out for new opportunities and self-advocate carefully, as no place is without its politics. In beautiful Boulder, where competing applicants are from literally all over the world because it's a place people want to be, competition is steep. As a result, some departments are quicker to change and more progressive than others, and salaries seem to be on par with the average but actually feel much lower in the expensive front range area. Also, though new initiatives and policies around accessibility and inclusiveness are definitely a great start, CU-B has a long way to go to attract a more diverse environment--the lack of racial and ethnic diversity is particularly frustrating.

review_title: Exploitation, Inequality, Systemic Issues, Administrative Bloat
pros: The people I worked with and met through my experiences here became some of my best friends! And I loved working with residents to help make their experience a little easier. My particular hall director was really nice and very helpful, made the whole experience bearable.
cons: The Administration treats its RA's about the same as any corporation treats their lowest-level employees. They say RA's are so generously compensated, but that's because it costs an arm and a leg to live in the dorms in Boulder. If you needed extra cash to.... IDK live, you have to get that approved and there is fierce competition for extra shifts at community centers. And as an RA, they say it equals 20-25 hrs of work every week, but if you're in your room/the building, (which you're supposed to be at least 5/7 days a week) someone could knock at any time. You're essentially 'always on' and if there is a more serious incident, you're required to respond any time of day. Plus, the role is such that you are forced to help and advise the same people that you live one door away from and sometimes share the bathroom with. And as part of your job you are supposed to maintain a positive relationship with them. And when the stress of all of that becomes too much, the mental health services for RA's were no different than any student, and the people who needed the 5 sessions of therapy or psychiatry ran out very fast. But of course that would cost actual money so they resisted when I suggested more sessions for RA's

pros:
-If your manager is nice and competent, your job should be fulfilling as long you're doing your work well.
-Good health benefits and vacation time.
-Nice views from campus.
cons:
-An incompetent, hostile manager can make your work life a living hell.
-OIT promoted and enabled people with a history of harassment towards others.
-Limited/no advancement opportunities.
-OIT leadership covered up an employee who drank enough alcohol to be over the legal limit and proceeded to drive a university vehicle on the clock. This happened at least twice during my tenure at CU. Nothing was ever done about it.
-Former team lead made a sexually harassing comment to an employee they managed and gave preferential funding to said person. OIT leadership covered up and blamed a different employee for the sexually harassing comment made by said team lead. 
-OIT skirted the management designation by using "team lead" but they were effectively a manager and telling others where to be.
-CU does not enforce bullying policy or do anything about harassment if the targeted individual isn't a member of a protected class.
-OIEC and CU at large are more concerned with who can sue them than doing anything about harassment.
-Consulting a lawyer before going to HR about a problematic employee is advised.
-HR can cover up incidents since it does not have to report to any state entity in the event of escalations.

job_title: IT Professional I in Boulder, CO
pros: There is a lot of autonomy in my position, and if you prove that you're not just going to do the minimum, you'll be noticed and probably advance easily after 1-2 years. The job itself is not that hard as far as workload goes, and there is an emphasis on not burning out technicians with too much work. The department is rapidly expanding, providing many opportunities for employees to shape the direction of the department as well as advance into frequently created positions of management or technical expertise. Almost all my teammates are good people that you're happy to work with. The team environment encourages technicians to watch out and help each other. There's good vacation time (21 days per year) and sick time, and great health benefits. There's almost no expectation for anyone to do work outside of normal working hours. When you go home, you don't have to think about work at all until you return to the office.
cons: The salary is not that good compared to many other System Administration jobs. The maximum raise you can get per year is barely enough to keep up with inflation, so the only way to make more money is to advance out of the entry level position. The knowledge that how good a job you do has very little to do with how much you get paid is not a good motivator.

job_title: IT Service Center Analyst in Boulder, CO
pros:
- On campus, which is convenient if your a student
- No state taxes taken out of paycheck
- Will work around your class schedule
cons:
CU is a giant machine with tens of thousands of different cogs. Unfortunately, they've setup their whole administration to work the same way faculty work with students: top down. On many occasions I suggested and even implemented solutions to problems, only to be reprimanded for doing something I wasn't asked to do. I wanted to do a good job and help students and faculty I was working with, but my superiors were more concerned about rules than they were about solutions. 

As a student, you're on the bottom of the totem pole, and there are levels upon levels of administrators and managers above you, so don't expect much reprieve from work over holidays or when you need it during finals. If you don't get your time covered, you HAVE to be at work for your shift.

review_title: I LOVED my time at CU right up until the end... and I've been hearing bad things ever since
pros:
- Great coworkers
- A feeling of stability and community
- Departments feel like their own "companies" where you don't have to deal with other parts of the school that don't affect your actual job
- Individual departments USED TO be able to  self-direct. This isn't true anymore.
cons:
- CU was already cutting funding while I was still there
- CU is being run like a business and not like a university
- Teachers and employees who do actual work aren't compensated fairly while CU administrators are given ridiculous benefits packages
- CU is very irresponsible about retirement plans and has previously lost an incredible amount of money by making terrible investments using employee retirement funds
- CU has decided to cut "program fees" as of 2018, so departments which used to be (or are currently) funded by program fees are likely to be eliminated or downsized, so it would be unwise to get a job working for them knowing there is no long-term plan for supporting them

job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Boulder, CO
pros: As a student at the time, this job was perfect. There are a ton of opportunities beyond just good service and I actually got the chance to work in my field. I learned so much and gained 2 years of experience that really boosted my resume for when I graduated. The pay was good, I was eligible for raises, and they were extremely accommodating of my class schedule. My superiors treated me with respect and would take time to mentor me to prepare me for the real world. Easily the best decision I made in college.
cons: Since this was a part-time position on top of school, it was difficult to keep up with everything in the office when I wasn't there. Deadlines would be changed and new projects introduced which would have been helpful information to know before coming into a shift. A better communication system would fix this.

review_title: Teaching jobs for instructors and adjunct faculty
pros:
This could be a great job for someone starting out as an college instructor or adjunct faculty.
Once you are in, you can earn job security. But right now administrators, not departments,
are setting the standards for teaching and service.
cons:
If you want to hold on to your teaching job, you must get high student evaluations.
This means allowing the students to set the larger curriculum goals, learning measures,
and work load. The big word for administrators is student retention. They are willing to do
almost anything to make students happy. This makes it difficult for instructors to maintain.
standards both both college- and discipline-level course work. What is really going on
is that instructors are being asked to teach these courses like these students were taught in
high school. All of this is undermining the standards of a once great university.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Boulder, CO
pros: There are great people here, there is plenty of lab space available, a decent work life balance is encouraged by most people here which is unlike many grad schools/programs so credit where it is due in all fairness.
cons: The pay is struggling to keep up with the real cost of living now that several tech companies are switching from CA to CO. There is way too much ego in some cases for what the lab here actually accomplish. The nickname "The Berkeley of the Rockies" is one they gave themselves and like any good nickname really only counts if that's what other people call them, which...they don't. They're not Berkeley level and don't let them tell you otherwise.

pros: Work at the pace you want since there is no profit incentive and no angry clients to keep happy. You work for yourself akin to a product company. Probably a great place to start as a developer because of less pressure, in general. Universities can be fun if you like academia.
cons: Not as high of a salary as other positions since there is no profit incentive. Coworkers you view as lazy probably won't be fired or reprimanded. You might be in a team that doesn't adhere strictly to best practices so you'll need more prep time for other interviews outside your team.

review_title: Working at the University of Colorado
pros: The University of Colorado supports diversity of both opinion and ethnicity.  That kind of support translates into both a better work environment and a better product, whether that product is research or education.
cons: Over the years the University has produced a fine cadre of current and former academics, many of whom choose to stay in the Boulder area after they leave employment at the University.  On the one hand, that's produced a local source of skilled, motivated people ready and able to support innovative industries.  On the other hand, that same close association between the the University and the town of Boulder has produced a sort of goldfish bowl / echo chamber.  In other words, the combined subculture of Town and Gown lends itself to impractical visions that are difficult to justify in the real world.

pros: The people I work with are great and it is a nice environment to work in. My superiors are supportive of my growth and work with my to improve my skills. I have been able to gain a lot of experience and meet a lot of people, while still maintaining a happy student life. My superiors are understanding of my status as a student and work with me to balance work and school.
cons: Although the environment is great and people are supportive and work well together, there is not a lot of opportunity for advancement. I am able to improve my skills in my own job area, but it is difficult to learn more about other areas and advance towards a wanted career path.

pros: People- fair number of dedicated members of the faculty and staff
cons: Management/Administration lack definitive goals, no accountability across organizations, lots of waste. I worked in the IT department for 4 years. In that time because of a lack of leadership it took 3 to 4 times as long to implement simple projects. There was no desire to have project managers, and they were resented by management, Operations staff, and the Program Managers when they attempted to perform the simplest, most accepted steps or methodology other organizations adapted a decade or two ago. The atmosphere across campus with a few exceptions is "that's not my job" as you are not rewarded for going above and beyond your duties. In IT, budgets are not kept, and no one was concerned with how much things were costing, or in the waste of time and money by inefficiency.

pros: You'll never be fired. I watched an employee not show up for work more than once or twice a month for over a year and never get fired. Medical benefits are pretty decent. You'll never work more than 30% of the time you're at work. 40 hour weeks are considered heavy.
cons: You will never make more than what you start at. 0% raises year after year. There is no chance of ever being promoted. Don't anger anyone liked by someone with more political clout than you. If you do, you're screwed. They will make your life miserable by assigning you the most horrid and boring work. Don't expect to get any real or usable benefits by working for the uni either. You get 2 classes a semester, but you pay the fees and you can't even register for the class until 2 days after the semester begins. Popular, standard required, and specialty classes are already full with a wait list, so it's never really a usable benefit.

job_title: Finance and Human Resources Manager in Boulder, CO
pros: Great flexibility.  Dynamic environment.  Unprecedented leave benefits (equivalent to 22 days of vacation and 15 days of sick leave per year).  4 different options for benefit plans.  Lots of opportunity for internal movement.  Most employees get a minimum 10% raise when they move jobs internally.  Cultures are different within each school and college.
cons: Very political environment.  Can be very old school - lots of paper and pen processes.  The HCM upgrade was an absolute joke and the university is spending millions to fix it.  University has also spent thousands defending themselves from sexual harassment suits.

pros: Flex work options (work from home, flexible hours), great technology (given an ipad or laptop and a smart phone to do work on the go), great people.  Lots of training and professional development opportunities.  There are also a lot of opportunities to move within the organization.  Great vacation and sick time for pro-exempt employees (22 days of vacation and 15 days of sick per year).  Benefits are good.
cons: Change is fast and unpredictable, doesn't seem to have a consistent vision.  Academic affairs and student affairs do not work in partnership.  Students are mostly rich and entitled, it's hard to get excited about working with these students.

review_title: CU Boulder is one of the country's strongest research campuses and in one of the most beautiful cities in the West.
pros: Great faculty and university.  For residents of Colorado, CU Boulder is a fantastic deal for higher education, although the locals often don't realize what they have.  For out of state students, it is still a great opportunity, but its not cheap.
cons: Colorado is 48 in the nation in funding education.  Like the UC campuses, the Colorado campuses are constantly facing resource reductions.  They have responded by behaving almost like private institutions.  Eventually they may literally be privatized.

review_title: Typical comfortable job in big government bureaucracy.
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Not stressful.
cons:
Difficult to improve processes or accomplish anything out of the ordinary.  No career advancement.  
During layoff I tried to transfer to other departments, but HR would not let me talk to hiring officials - told me I must apply with outside candidates!  Incredible - they are laying me off, but won't facilitate a transfer to other open positions for which I was fully qualified.  I'm not asking for the job.  I'm asking to be given the opportunity to talk to the hiring official for a possible transfer.  Do I not deserve that after more than 10 years of loyal service?  This happened twice.  Perfect example of big government red tape wasting tax payer dollars.

review_title: For grad students: Great place to earn teaching experience
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Boulder, CO
pros: In the Social Sciences there is significant opportunity for grad students to receive teaching experience. I began as a Teaching Assistant for several faculty but then earned a Graduate Part-Tume Instructor (GPTI) position due to my excellent student evaluations and that I was able to teach a course that current faculty were unable to. This included designing syllabi, exams, and lectures. I had a GPTI for both small (20 students) classes and large (200 students). Additionally, the Grad Student Teaching Program is a very hands-on process of earning a certificate in teaching; an excellent addition to resumes in academia.
cons: The only draw back is that the teaching certification process is lengthy, a bit redundant, and--at times--useless. Many of the required improvement learning sessions are directionless and not at all what they are advertised to be. On another topic, the pay, while better that a full-time, temporary instructor, is pretty abysmal.

review_title: For the right people, it can be a great place
pros:
* Opportunity and freedom to pursue areas of interest which would also benefit CU
* Culture of learning, innovation and striving to improve services in my unit. This can be unusual.
* Trusted by manager, so I have freedom within boundaries, making it a great place to work.
* "Hardware flush", any reasonable case for R&D on a new gadget is approved.
cons:
* Got the wrong manager? Look out. CU HR will often be heard saying "Well, you are an at will employee, better not make waves". 
* Salaries in some departments are lower than others, watch out for that as CU HR will not intervene to ensure parity across similar positions in different departments.
* Expect a lower salary than private industry, this should not surprise the experienced professional.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Boulder, CO
pros: The training program is very good, I really felt comfortable giving advice after finishing training. The advisors are always helpful and get quick answers for you. Workers are free to do homework or other activities while not working with a customer. Immediate pay raise after completing training and consistently 6 months.
cons: There are certainly some very busy times of the school year (anytime the bill is coming up and at the end of the year) which can be a little hectic. Also, there are obviously some customers who can be pretty negative. If you don't have a disposition to let angry remarks slide off your back, this might not be a good job for you.

pros: Lots of opportunities, lots of things to put on your resume.  If you look for a job at CU while you're a student, you're bound to find something and most likely will be given the opportunity to rise in the ranks and get the knowledge you need to succeed elsewhere.
cons: The pros are somewhat of a con.  As a student employee, they groom you to leave.  There is seldom opportunity for a student employee to stay on past their graduation.  Forget about ever getting paid if you don't have work-study.  They thrive on putting students with work study (where they only have to pay 30% of your salary) in key positions and then churning them over once those students leave.

review_title: Computer science PhD program has good faculty but is hampered by funding, student quality and poor facilities
pros: The computer science faculty are smart and capable. There are connections to the vibrant Boulder startup community. Boulder is a beautiful area with many outdoor opportunities and the cost of housing is much less than San Francisco, New York City, etc. The cultural and social opportunities in Boulder and the Denver area are good for a city of it's size. Student compensation seems adequate and on par with US graduate programs in computer science.
cons: Though it varies by lab, the program does not attract the best, most prepared students or adequate research funding. The building (Engineering Center) is substandard and has few windows, making the working conditions difficult.

pros: You design your own work schedule and there are usually plenty of people available to pick up a shift or trade for one if you need to change something and it's always close to where you live because you have to be a student to have the position.
cons: Minimum wage is simply what it is. It's never fun to be paid the minimum but it can be worth it between the schedule flexibility and if you're working in the dining halls you can get a meal with break.

review_title: Pretty nice place to be a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Our department doesn't have the newest facilities, but they care about their graduate students and I have enjoyed my time here so far. I feel that I will be well prepared when I look for a job. Boulder is a beautiful place to live and work. There are many opportunities to get outdoors when you need a break.
cons: The basic on-campus healthcare facilities were fine, but the lack of further coverage has left me disappointed (e.g., one eye exam a year and no coverage of glasses/contacts, no dental coverage). I don't know how this healthcare coverage compares to other universities. Cost of living—particularly rent—seems like it is rising quickly in Boulder relative to our graduate stipends.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros:
- Great environment as far as flexibility and great supervisors
- The Research and development environment provides new and different projects routinely
- You get to work with extremely intelligent faculty and staff
- Great benefits (for faculty) as far as PTO, 401k/pension and medical
cons:
- The pay is significantly less than industry (even after balancing out the better benefits)
- Very flat hierarchal structure. By that I mean there is no room to advance / grow
- Working with students is a double edged sword. It is fun to mentor and teach, especially when you find the right student. The student turnover is always a problem.

pros: Friendly, open-door communication; reasonable compensation for size, mostly committed, diligent staff (with some exceptions) who want to serve the university and its' mission.
cons: Overly siloed, and sometimes jumbled internal communication about direction for individual units; wide variance in competency and capabilities of mid/senior managers and their ability to trickle down information regarding specific goals and objectives from senior leadership (some of this was unavoidable as it seems senior management wasn't sure of the right objectives.)

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boulder, CO
pros: University of Colorado benefits package contributes 85% to 90% of medical premiums.  The package includes medical, dental, vision, life insurance, short-term and long-term disability, retirement savings and wellness programs.  CU also contributes handsomely to the two core retirement plans it offers.  Free eco-bus pass.  Work with a highly skilled workforce.  Exceptional quality of life in Colorado.
cons: Average pay, but heavy workload, with high quality standards which may encourage working overtime.  As a college town, housing affordability is a detriment to the living in Boulder, so most people must commute from neighboring communities.

review_title: Time to break some old habits
pros: Outstanding medical, vacation, and sick leave benefits. Able to work from home. Eco Passes to all employees.
cons: Parking is awful, and if you have to park on campus, which you most likely do if you can't get public transportation easily, it is expensive to get a parking pass, and goes up every year. There are a lot of politics and bureaucracy in the workplace, and it really makes it hard to have any positive change. Pay is not competitive in many cases.

job_title: IT Professional I in Boulder, CO
pros: Low stress, beautiful campus, flexible schedule. It was nice to work and be able to take classes for free. My position was in a department so as an IT Professional I was independent and could make changes and improvements as needed.
cons: No career development, no raises in 5 years, disrespectful managers. I tried for years to develop my job but the campus had no interest in the skills I had developed and getting I more organized so I moved on to a much higher paying job.

job_title: Student Assistant V in Boulder, CO
pros: The environment was very welcoming and they were somewhat flexible with your schedule and life. Every day was a new challenge.
cons: There wasn't much structure and the management was all over the place. My supervisor would lie about deadlines to get us motivated, would lie about staying late to "get us right on schedule" when we could clearly see everything was the same as it was left by the team. They also may have gotten someone fired at another department just because the person didn't do what they wanted the person to do.

review_title: Poor pay and almost no oversight of graduate students.  Our department head could care less about graduate students.
pros: The undergrads are fun to teach.  While some really struggle to stay awake in-between runs on the slopes, others are very active, smart, and engaged.  I don't think there are really any benefits, grad students still have to pay for health care, gym membership, and everything else separately.
cons: Grad students are underpaid, which is standard across universities.  Still, little effort is made to improve things here.  I don't think there are really any benefits, grad students still have to pay for health care, gym membership, and everything else separately.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros:
CU has a strong physics graduate program.  The program is one of the largest in the country and therefore affords students a wide range of research opportunities.  These opportunities are further expanded because of the numerous national laboratories in the area.

The faculty I have interacted with, particularly in my research and advance classes have been top notch and supportive.  The office is also friendly and exceptionally competent.
cons: This is not so much a criticism of the University of Colorado but of graduate school in general.  Graduate school, especially a PhD program is not for everyone.  Also your experience will vary greatly based on who you take classes with and who your research advisor is.

review_title: Maintenance Department Review for CU Rec Center
job_title: FItness Technician Supervisor in Boulder, CO
pros: My boss (Troy Burbidge) is the nicest, most forgiving boss I've ever had. He is ok with you being 20-30 minutes to work in the mornings and is all around very laid back. The work consists of cleaning and maintaining all the equipment at the Rec Center, and it is rather easy work, you just need some mechanical knowledge and the ability to use a screwdriver ;)
cons: Sometimes it feels very slow and the work can seem pointless. Scraping gum off of machines can get old after a while, however it is rare that we do this.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: I interacted with faculty that inspired me to imagine a unique future for myself. I was lucky enough to be in a department where I had access to funding. Health insurance... it's not awesome and you pay up front for access to it but it's better than nothing.
cons: The University has consistently prioritized profits over faculty safety and health during Covid-19 pandemic. The University chooses a business structure that informs the lack of diversity within their student body. The homogenous white, affluent population makes the university a difficult place to live for its minority students. The University forces graduate teaching assistants to pay student fees that have absolutely nothing to do with their experience as a CU faculty member.

review_title: LASP is the best place I've ever worked
pros: All employees are respected and empowered, from the highest level director to the student working in inventory.  Young people are able to do work that only much more senior people would do at a bigger company.  The teams are competent, efficient, and put out really amazing work.
cons: Since LASP is part of CU, which is part of the State of Colorado, there can be a lot of red tape that wouldn't be an issue at a private company.  Also, the pay doesn't keep up with industry, though the vacation and retirement matching exceed other companies.  Right now, contracts are running thin and work will be tight for a while.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Flexible work hours. I appreciated the excellent mentor-ship provided by the various professors I have worked for.   Professors I worked for appreciated my work and enjoyed teaching the students.
cons: Was not appreciated by department management, who attempted to force me to work as an hourly grader, being paid half the teaching assistant salary for twice the required hours.

review_title: UCB understands how to help students live a balanced life work life, but there is little room for vertical movement.
pros: Very understanding of the competing obligations students hold and are excellent at balancing work with academics, social life, and just plain growing up in college. There is lots of support and mentoring available to aid in the development of young professional careers. Employees are auto-enrolled to a retirement plan.
cons: The pay is not that great but it is understandable as the University has never been blessed with large amounts of cash. There also seems to be little room for vertical movement in terms of increased job responsibilities or pay raises.

pros: Working at CU Boulder is great. It is in a beautiful location. As a student, working as an intramural official can be very challenging and rewarding. I learned a lot about the game of basketball, as well as how to mediate conflict.
cons: As an intramural official, some of the players can be extremely rude. Some teams are made of entitled brats who are still trying to live out their glory days of high school sports. Pay could be better, but you are paid more for refereeing basketball, which is hard.

review_title: Typical higher ed environment - big enough that there really is a community for everyone.
pros: Great activists and people trying to work towards social justice. I worked in residence life and the student leadership was phenomenal and there was a great focus on social justice. You can't really beat living in Boulder, either!
cons: As is typical in a higher ed environment, there is always more work to do if you want to do it. Creating a work-life balance can be a challenge, especially working in residence life. Battling the higher ups, especially in regards to social justice initiatives, can be a challenge.

job_title: Discovery Learning Apprentice in Boulder, CO
pros: Flexible work schedule so I could fit in time around my classes. I learned a lot about research in graduate school even though I didn't do a lot on my own, but working with a graduate student for an entire year really gave me insight into how graduate school works.
cons: Communication with the professor that was paired with me was an issue as he was never available. This is why I spent most of my time with the graduate student I was paired with.

review_title: Good work in the world, but "Do more with less" on steroids.
pros: CU-Boulder provides good opportunities for doing good work in the world, supporting and promoting higher education, and there are some great people here -- faculty, staff, and students. Good entrepreneurial spirit.
cons: Some downsides include major budget shortages and a chronic and growing "Do more with less" mentality. Also, many of the administrators are academics without good management skills or training.  There are a few notable exceptions.

review_title: I worked at the Office of Orientation at the University of Colorado at Boulder
pros: I really enjoyed the people I got to work with. Despite the long hours, the days go by pretty quickly. You also get paid to eat at the C4C dining hall at CU which is especially good during the summer because they're trying to impress the parents eating there.
cons: Long hours. You will often work the full 6am-6pm shift, and often you are left just sitting around waiting for an event to end or for someone to tell you what to do.

pros: What your job will lack in advancement opportunities, it makes up for in a vibrant campus and great people. Depending on the department, casual attire and flexible work schedules are attainable. Given lots of vacation. Despite state funding concerns, leadership appears to have a very forward-thinking plan for how to survive and thrive.
cons: Little room to move up the ladder (especially if you have little to no prior supervision experience). Departments appear to be understaffed across the campus. Lots of people wearing multiple hats and yet the pay is less than my peers outside of higher ed are making.

pros: Working at JILA, the people are fantastic. Everyone loves their job and is motivated and smart. The resources here such as the instrument and electronics shops are invaluable and not found in many places. Boulder itself is a great town.
cons: The career path of many gradute students is geared toward unrealistic academic positions. There just aren't that many out there. Professors focus to an extreme on science and less on practical applications, so it is important to define your own goals and not those of someone else.

review_title: Amazing place to learn some new technologies, good place if you love mountain biking, trekking.
pros: Location: Boulder is undoubtedly one of the friendliest towns in USA. Great places to eat. Very safe to travel even at 3AM in the morning. There are a lot of breweries out there if you like trying out local makes. Also a great place if you love mountain biking. There are couple of very good trails just 10 to 15 min walk from campus.
cons: Library: Math library usually closes very early on Fridays. Also they have limited hours during Summer. The Norlin library is open late but only during exam weeks.

pros: It's great to be on campus and be part of a dynamic educational environment.
cons: The University does not pay well, and it is a slow moving bureaucracy. It's quite inefficient, and they are frequently updating procedures, but then they don't provide enough guidance on the updates, or worse, the updates are fraught with numerous problems.

job_title: Studio Art Monitor in Boulder, CO
pros: I really liked working at the university of colorado because I was able to work alongside other students like myself. I was a studio monitor in the art department and being around people who loved the same things I did was really amazing.
cons: It was harding working at the university of colorado boulder because I also went to school there part time. I wasn't given a lot of guidance in my position and it made it more difficult to know what to do.

pros: Great environment, the place is beautiful. Great employees for the most part, you get to work with Students or around them. The University is making a difference in the world and in peoples lives.
cons: Can be a very political environment, state workers are often negatively stereotyped in the media. Each department has separate needs and policies so there is a large amount of divergent policies depending on what department your in. The state legislature determines pay for classified staff removing any monetary incentive from the management in the University.

pros: Great location, nice people, interesting projects, important work
cons: The University of Colorado Boulder does not value longevity of employees with regard to salary increases. Overtime, if you continue working for the university your salary will be stunted. They always hire outside people for more than they are willing to pay current employees (regardless of performance). Also, the fact that many departments try to keep salary secretive, even though our salaries are all posted publicly each year, shows that those departments do not want to be transparent about these salary issues.

review_title: [engineering graduate student] Great location, not great compensation/benefits
job_title: Engineering Graduate Student in Boulder, CO
pros:
*Living in Boulder: mountains (snowsports, hiking, climbing, beautiful national parks) & culture (restaurants, concerts, Denver closeby)
*Good professors, classes, & research
cons:
*difficulty to get funding
*health insurance isn't covered (and even if you pay for your own Student Gold health insurance the coverage is not good if services aren't done on-campus during business hours)
*work in crappy building -- few windows

review_title: low pay,  Corporate-like managment without principled values
job_title: Research Assistant At LASP in Boulder, CO
pros:
Great scenery through the window.
Good retirement benefits.
cons:
1)Low pay. Employees like me cannot live in Boulder and are pushed in the suburbs, partaking  in  the daily 60,000 commutes to Boulder.
2)The lack of moral principles of  Chancellor DiStefano.
Back in 2006, professor Churchill was fired, ultimately for his political views.  The incident illustrates the lack of principle of the-now chancellor DiStefano. As faculty members, we cannot  be sure that we will be supported by the Chancellor if the public image of CU is at stake, whatever the academic freedom claims , whatever the moral principles.

review_title: Secure but hard to get into
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Boulder, CO
pros: Benefits for classified staff: strict 40-hour work weeks, tuition credits (9 cr per year), PTO, Sick Days, AND paid holidays. It's a big campus so there's less interaction with other employees; staff council hosts lunches or breakfasts once a semester to increase interaction.
cons: Classified positions do not have the flexibility of working from home, even when times are slow. Snow days are not granted very often, even when roads are terrible. It's hard to transfer to other campuses or move up.

review_title: Has one of everything, unlike MIT that might have 5 of everything
pros:
This review relates to biological sciences departments
-resourceful learning environment with very friendly and smart people that are willing to help you out
-advisors are very supportive of your own research directions
-time off policies are very generous
-mountains are 30mins. away
cons: -postdocs tend to get same benefits as research associates (health, dental, tuition reimbursement, 403b), but once you get your own fellowship, you have to renegotiate your benefits because the default is to reduce your benefits to only health & dental

pros: Flexible schedule, allowed you to do homework on the job, overall a very easy job.
cons: If you don't have seniority for good shifts, then you'll get stuck working graveyard shifts.  Plus there seemed to be a lot of drama among, RAs, dorm residents, and management.

review_title: Good place for a graduate student
pros:
- Lots of interesting seminars and opportunities to expand your horizons
- Excellent social opportunities
- It's Boulder, which is very nice, with tons of outdoor activities around
cons:
- It's a large state school, so bureaucracy is omnipresent
- Depending on where you live, undergrads can be annoying
- They fouled up my paycheck several times, and it was difficult to correct (see first point re: bureaucracy)

pros:
Very cushy government job. I enjoyed literally none of the work I did between three units/three positions, but I can’t complain about the benefits, the scheduling flexibility I had in my unit, and virtual impossibility of being fired/disciplined.

Most of my days were spent in meetings, and my colleagues and I were discouraged from doing anything productive. As the saying goes, hurry up and do nothing.
cons:
- Bureaucracy: there were barriers (many arbitrary) to getting anything done. There were also millions of meetings. Everything at CU invokes committees, sub committees, working groups, etc. I’m pretty certain that most employees don’t do anything but go to meetings, and unfortunately, those meetings generally accomplish nothing.
- No decision-makers or propriety: everyone, from the ground floor, to middle managers, to vice chancellors and provosts, were afraid to make decisions about anything. Therefore, almost everything was referred to committees (see above), which accomplished nothing and wasted time. The saying “designed by a committee” has negative connotations, but at CU, it’s the way of life. I don’t know how anyone thinks groupthink and bandwagoning is healthy, but alas, that’s what we do. Because nobody makes any decisions, nobody is held accountable for institutional failures, such as the ridiculously flawed D2L deployment in 2011.
- Complete lack of accountability across the enterprise. Personnel: while I appreciated that I couldn’t be fired, there was an abundance of bad apples, unmotivated, lazy or otherwise ineffective employees. Institutionally: the lack of accountability meant massive waste, abuse, inefficiency, and failed/useless projects.
- Politics: within my last and most recent unit at CU, the amount of kowtowing between teams was insane. We were prohibited from asking questions, making suggestions, or pointing out issues — even on day to day stuff. For example, my boss believed that submitting a ticket for internet issues at my desk would be deeply offensive to our colleagues in networking.
- Lack of collaboration: For reasons above, we were unable to openly, transparently, or objectively communicate or collaborate with other teams. I can’t count the number of times my team’s efforts were being duplicated by 22 other groups on campus.
- Poor treatment of students:  Nobody cares about satisfying or serving our students. Students, despite paying sometimes as much as $55,000 a year, don’t deserve any minimum level of customer service, treatment, ROI, or services. 
- Thankless and guiltless: the work was thankless, and I witnessed a lot of unsavory and ill informed decisions.  I saw millions of dollars be pissed away by the university, with absolutely no sense of stewardship or accountability by anyone. CU is a very expensive school, and it’s high price tag and out of state population more than make up for any “lack of state funding”. It’s really disheartening seeing students/families sell/indebt their souls and then see CU waste money.

pros: CU Boulder has given me many opportunities to move forward with my career, as well as an exceptional PhD education in chemical physics.
cons: The cost of living in Boulder can be very high.  Especially compared to the RA salary.  Other than that, there are not many down sides to this.

pros:
-I went from grad student to lecturer and they really have stood by me. Something I think many departments and universities might not offer. 
-Decent administrative support. Students are great. 
-You get to work with some incredible faculty and staff
cons: -The department I was with specifically doesn't always understand the variety of diversity that exists. Mental health support is minimal, and difficult to get understood.

job_title: Student Assistant IV in Boulder, CO
pros:
Awesome Place to work at. It is one of the best places with handicap access and all other amenities / features. 
People who work here are generally very soft-spoken and caring (most of the credit goes to the place)
Best climate to work. And if you are a pet lover, then most of the offices are pet-friendly.
cons: If you are from a fast paced lifestyle, working here might seem slow (and sometimes unprofessional - in a good way) For instance, in board meetings, unlike DC, we don't wear suits.

pros: At CU-Boulder, there are great benefits, such as free tuition up to nine hours per year, choices of health care and dental care.
cons: At the recent meeting between Admin and employees, the bottom line was that compression had not been met.   With the cost of living in Colorado higher, especially Boulder, the University has not met the needs of the employees.  A recent raise in February raised 500 employees above the poverty level.  The current raises set at 2% do not keep up with Boulder or CU costs, such as parking increases and tuition.

review_title: CU Boulder - Love it or Hate it
pros: Many of the people you work with at the University, whether Staff or Faculty are good people.
cons: After working with various groups across campus, in particular the Office of Information Technology, the leadership across campus is very weak compared to what you find in the business sector.  Their poor leadership can have negative impacts on your day to day job.

review_title: A great academic environment to grow.
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Very high quality professors and administrators, endless opportunities for research, excellent support for grant writing, the staff is open to moving you to the best place for you. Very good benefits and support.
cons: Overall pay is low, but the benefits make up for some of the low pay. It is easy to get lost in the crowd. Hard work is not always appreciated in such a busy environment and the expectations are very high.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: As a graduate student in MCDB, salary was ~30K which was comparable to other programs in areas with similar cost of living if not a bit higher. Also living in Boulder is fantastic. Climbing, skiing, running, hiking etc. is world class. Atmosphere is pretty relaxed at CU with lots of very smart people who also like to play hard in the mountains.
cons: Very isolated from a critical mass of research and industry as may be found in larger cities near the coasts. This makes it hard to find work in this area after graduating.

pros: Time to do homework. Awesome people and bosses. Most of the time you can just sit and do your homework. Most of the customers are pretty cool and easy to handle.
cons: Any technician jobs can have hard to handle customers and this one is no different. The only problem is some people feel entitled to getting their computers fixed and that a free service should always handle their problems.

pros: The best job you will find in college that allows you to conform to your class schedule. The management is easy to work with and will help you grow as an employee and prepare you for roles when you leave. Save money on groceries by working in a Dining Unit and gain practical skills as well
cons: Sometimes, the service industry can suck. But it doesn’t get worse than that.

review_title: Can't imagine NOT doing this work!
pros: I love my job - I have a lot of variety and work with great people. I have the opportunity to serve on a variety of committees and develop my leadership and interpersonal skills on a daily basis. My favorite part of my job is working with motivated students who want to excel in their career development.
cons: There aren't a ton of opportunities to advance within each department. It can also be challenging to maintain work-life balance during the busier times of the semester.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boulder, CO
pros:
- Great Benefits (Health, dental, vision, etc.)
- Enjoyable work environment/nice people
- You are in beautiful Boulder
- Opportunity for growth
- Health vacation and sick time
cons: So far I haven't experienced many cons, the people are great, I enjoy the work and the campus. Not much to complain about. I guess sometimes some of my work gets tedious and repetitive but any job can be like that at times.

pros:
Get to work with outstanding professors and faculty.
Intellectual Environment, great opportunity to learn more and build a resume.
Students are friendly and easy to work with.
Campus is beautiful year-round, as long as you don't mind some snow.
Received great training.
cons:
Did not get a lot of feedback for job as Teaching Assistant.
Faculty are very busy and often don't have time to talk.
Salary and hours are often times non-negotiable.

pros: I've had numerous different supervisors while I was here and all of them have taught me skills that I'll be using for the rest of my life. Rather than just delegating busy work, I was given tasks that required critical thinking and problem solving. In the office that I was with, the majority of staff were always looking to improve their methods and approaches to effectively impact the student population.
cons: I haven't noticed any substantial problems while working with the faculty and staff here, but occasionally, internal politics can slow the workflow.

review_title: 8years experience as a cna and affiliated jobs within scope of certification
pros: This field can be gratifying daily for we all as a human race will have to be taken care of by some one in their lifetime
cons: Their are many cons in this field as well example caring for a patient with mental illness the patient strikes you as the professional it must be handled as a behaviour not take it personal

pros: The culture of learning is excellent.  Working with students is fun and fulfilling.  My colleagues are all people I respect and enjoy working with.  They are some of the most intelligent, hard working and passionate people I know.  The academic calendar affords lots of time off.
cons: Limited upward mobility.  Compensation is poor compared to industry.  The office and research space on campus for our department is terrible and the University seems mostly indifferent.

review_title: Don't trust my judgement, I'm easy to please, but I like working here
pros: Both student jobs I've had were on/near campus and had flexible hours to work around students' schedules. There are occasionally opportunities to move around within OIT and plenty of employment opportunities here after you graduate, though not usually on the same team.
cons: High turnover rate since people are always graduating. Staying on the same team as staff after graduating is rarely an option. Also, my building is full of adult employees so I can feel a little out of place sometimes.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: I was happy with my experience as a GTA at Boulder. In my department (applied math), graduate student feedback was well received by instructors, making for a good work culture.  I was hired for part time work, and it truly was part time. The department always kept the work to about 20 hrs/week. The compensation is going in the right direction and has gotten quite reasonable for a graduate student stipend. Support the CRC!
cons: I didn't always like the instructors' approaches to grading, but, as I said, they were receptive to feedback.

review_title: Good school but not much interaction with other faculty
pros: Great Location, good job benefits, lots of good outdoor activities, friendly people all over the city.
cons: I feel like instructors are like second-class citizens, Tenured/TenureTrack faculty are most respected by everyone and even though, instructors take the most teching work load are thought of as just doing their job. I feel like the level which one is respected is directly correlated with 1-which school you graduated from 2-how much money you bring to campus

review_title: Good compensation and benefits, however somewhat chaotic
job_title: IT Technician II in Boulder, CO
pros: Was given great equipment to work with, good compensation/benefits and worked with a lot of intelligent and skilled people.
cons: I feel there needs to be more emphasis on professionalism and teamwork.  Supervisors need to be available and willing to mentor new employees on processes unique to the University.

review_title: Great place to work and grow
pros: The benefits are great and include an EcoPass and tuition benefits in addition to options for health, dental, and vision insurance. There are discounts for events and many appreciation events throughout the year. Being on campus keeps you young!
cons: Since we work for the state, and the state doesn't spend a lot of money on higher education, sometimes it feels hard to get a raise.

pros: I've only worked in one department on campus, but everyone here values work-life balance. The perks of working for a large, flagship university are the amount of opportunities shoved in your face on a regular basis. Plus tuition benefit if you want to take some classes!
cons: Coordinating with campus partners can sometimes be a pain. Some offices are really flaky and make empty promises. The senior administration of the entire university system could use some updating (ie, not just be entirely made of old, white men).

review_title: Beautiful location but challenging to get work done
pros: Campus and the city of Boulder are a big attraction.  Lots of freedom; very little top-down leadership. An "on you're on your own" work culture. Flexible work schedule.
cons: Less than stellar business operations behind the scenes. CU is laden with antiquated buildings, business systems and processes. Faculty run CU, not the expected  traditional leadership organizational structure. Strong internal competition between internal units.

review_title: There's some truth to the stereotypes about working in the public sector
job_title: Marketing Communications Coordinator in Boulder, CO
pros: Hard to get fired! As long as you show up and smile at meetings, you can be as lazy as you want.
cons: Hard to get fired! I saw more people float by waiting for their retirement than people actually motivated to make impact. Not a good environment for motivated people excited to make waves in their industry.

job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Very interesting place to work, good colleagues, good environment, good projects
cons: In some cases the manager is not good at management. There is really no promotions in research, it is not a career for the most part as you come and go with the grant funding. With that said there are some very good opportunities to get valuable experience doing interesting work that you can use to get into a career position elsewhere.

pros: I love the people I work with. The small environment in which I work provides an encouraging environment for team building. Which allows us to be more productive on the job.
cons: The upper management doesn't seem to care about us at all. Especially recently, we have not been provided essential funds which has caused us to be understaffed. This has put pressure on my coworkers and I in order to compensate.

review_title: Poor teaching and mentorship in graduate program.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: I learned a great deal from my time in graduate school and was able to connect with excellent scientists in my field.
cons: The classroom preparation and mentorship for research was terrible. Poor communication, no teaching of research practice skills, no explanation of the metacognition of research. Aside from a few exceptions, the coursework is poorly taught with most classes consisting of lecture with little learning and no practical skills. Too much focus on theory with no application to actually use these concepts.

review_title: Great opportunities as graduate research assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Your experience as a paid GRA totally depends on your adviser. Overall though, the pay is pretty good and the opportunities to learn, and mature in your career are good. The school is very well equipped in engineering and aerospace. Flexible hours.
cons: The rent in Boulder is quite high and getting higher with Google constructing a campus in town. Family housing prices are reasonable though. The hours are flexible but can leave you feeling like you should always be working more.

pros:
The University is a huge organization, and so any comments need to be taken as relating only to my area. Reasonably good work space.
Management does not micro-manage
Excellent benefits and Time Off
Great Co-workers
cons:
State system is very limiting. Managers are unable to provide incentives for doing good work. 
Work load can be extremely heavy
State system--raises have been frozen for three years.

review_title: Great place to go to school
job_title: Science Discovery TA in Boulder, CO
pros: Great education in state is affordable and is a highly ranked university to attend. Have had little trouble proving my degree is worth alot to employers.
cons:
Large classes at the lower level that would explain better off taking at a community college for half the price. First two years of credit hours are pretty much a rip off.
There is a 10 dollar an hour fixed pay for LAs and TAs so no room for moving up 

No benifits for TAs

pros: Other student employees and salary employees were great overall. Lot of fun working with great people. Pay raises every semester, upwards of $0.50+ for the first year.
cons: The work itself isn't great. You're dealing with recycling from across the campus, sometimes not so bad, sometimes week old baby diaper in the recycling.

review_title: I love my work environment, but I don't love the pay or the higher admin.
pros: The students, friendly staff, flexibility.
cons: The pay isn't enough to live in Boulder. I have a master's degree and make 36,000, which isn't enough to pay rent or daycare for myself and my 2 kids. Sometimes I don't even have enough for food. I'm right above the poverty line for a single parent in a job at a higher education institute that requires a master's or phd.

review_title: It was about the same as other teaching assistantships
pros: The weather and view were probably the best parts, which I think says a lot.  In general, there was a lot of freedom, within the obvious confines of course requirements.
cons: The benefits were very low, but comparable to other places, so that's not that surprising.  My immediate supervisors were always great, but it was hard to not feel that we were a nuisance to the upper management.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Getting paid to earn a degree is a pretty excellent situation. The work/life balance is spectacular if your advisor is good. I think about it as a paid apprenticeship, and I love it.
cons: Everything about the experience, and I mean everything, depends on your advisor. If you're not desperate, ask whether your appointment includes 100% pay in the summer - makes about $5k difference in annual salary.

pros: Next to impossible to get fired. Above average days of paid vacation. Most positions have long periods of downtime throughout the day.
cons: Pretty much all of the cons of working in the public sector apply here. Low pay. Unmotivated coworkers who are perfectly fine of doing the minimum. Environment not conducive to learning skills on the job (ironically, despite it being an institute of higher education).

review_title: Good part-time job for a student
pros: The other students I work with are great and so is the supervisor (former teacher). Hours are flexible except for when I hold lab, but I can grade things on my own wherever I want and then log  the hours online.
cons: Grading is really really boring. There is definitely a language barrier with some students (I have mostly freshman.) Was told I was getting a $1 raise after doing it for a semester but I did not.

pros:
- Weathered the economic crisis better than most universities.
- For the humanities: good place for very traditional academics, particularly those researching 19th century or earlier.
- Excellent support and faculty in the sciences.
- Interesting work happening in social sciences, particularly Ethnic Studies and Women's and Gender Studies.
- The setting is beautiful.
cons:
-Outdated approaches in humanities research
-Little support for genuinely innovative and interdisciplinary research in the humanities
-Lack of diversity in faculty and student body
-Teaching often devalued
-Lacking programs in important fields like contemporary Middle Eastern studies

pros: Pay is decent for the work you do, grill is very busy during football games
cons: food preparation is not sanitary, we would sell pretzels that were months old, managers told us we had to. At the end of the day you have to count up everything.... It is so annoying when you have to count 400 plastic cups.

review_title: Great school, but your salary doesn't support cost of living
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Boulder is great, and the university has a good reputation.
cons: The pay for graduate students isn't enough to cover rent in Boulder (even with roommates) because of Boulder's zoning laws. Depending on your appointment, you might also be forced to pay into a retirement plan you're ineligible from actually using later. Parking can be impossible and absurdly overpriced. (Certain jobs will provide you with a bus pass, but some of them won't.)

pros: Twenty two days per year vacation
cons: No manager shares issues with the level above.   Managers survive by making the level above think everything is handled.  Consequently the entire hierarchy is clueless what goes on.  Our department tried to keep a service attitude, and to address issues that others brought to us rather than pass the buck.  But this went against the grain and didn't survive once we lost a strong leader.

job_title: Senior Database Administrator in Boulder, CO
pros: Team was great and they were very talented some of the best to work with. The group was always on the cutting edge of technology also, which is great for a college.
cons: The upper management is where the issues are. They have people in place that should not be managing and they are uncertain and make rash decisions only based on themselves and the money they can get directly.

review_title: CU won't stand up to its faculty
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Boulder, CO
pros: Boulder is beautiful. One of the top city/town in America, imo. You have world-class access to beautiful nature trails just 5-10 minutes away.
cons: CU really wants to be a top research institution (and they are), but they also have terrible impostor syndrome. They will bend over backward for faculty, because they are terrified of faculty leaving for 1. better paid or 2. more prestigious appointments. This encourages many abuses.

pros: One would undergo a great learning curve while working at the University of Colorado ITS office. The manager is amicable, patient, and guides you through your work.
cons: I can not find any downsides of working at CU ITS office. The only one I would say is that my office space is little cramped.

pros: Although it would be nice to have a monthly stipend, compensation of room and board is fair since Boulder housing is so expensive. Great access to resources (free tutoring, etc).  Nicely located.  Nice facilities overall. Rewarding meeting so many people.  Overall, a great experience for a couple of years.
cons: It can be frustrating working in the same environment that you live.  Documenting residents is a necessary but irritating element of the job.

review_title: Great institution but not centrally managed, tough to manage across organizational lines
job_title: Principal Gift Officer in Boulder, CO
pros: CU Boulder values lifelong learning for all of its employees.  There are many opportunities to grow personally and professionally.
cons: Each department of each academic unit manages its affairs differently than the others.  This independence helps them be "fast" in meeting their constituents'' needs but makes it very difficult for those who much manage across organizational lines to be productive.

review_title: World-class research environment in a beautiful location.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Boulder is a beautiful, safe, and friendly place to work. The weather is fantastic. The department in which I work is productive, friendly, and mostly supportive. The University pulls in a lot of funding for research.
cons: Like all large universities, it seems there are frequently discrepancies between different departments, schools, and colleges. Administration can be slow and unresponsive at times, but again, this is a symptom of many large research universities.

review_title: Great educational institution in an amazingly beautiful location
pros: The University of Colorado is an institution that values education, I have found many career opportunities in the university moving positions many times to increase my level of authority and learn new skills. I have found it to be a very stable employer.
cons: The university doesn't have the best public image due to historical issues and higher education does not offer as many perks as similar industry positions.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Nice facilities, sufficient stiped, some top researchers, and a strong sense of community.  And living in Boulder is like always being on vacation.
cons: There is decent attrition. Probably typical of most graduate programs. Boulder is kinda pricey.   You have to develop your own skills as a researcher.

job_title: Peer Career Advisor in Boulder, CO
pros:
Very flexible work hours (especially if you are a student employee)
Amazing colleagues who are motivated and driven individuals 
My bosses were very invested in my growth and development and very willing to help me
cons: There are a limited number of positions that are available at any given time as well. Because this is a University many jobs require graduate degrees.
