review_title: PhD Student in Astrophysical & Planetary Sciences
pros: Excellent programs in the natural sciences. Very supportive department. Good stipends. There is an excellent sense of community among the grad students.
cons: Cost of living is moderately high. Health insurance for dependents is extremely expensive. Time to graduation can be a bit long and there isn't much incentive from the administration to keep time to graduation short.

pros: At the department, there is a strong emphasis on self-care and teamwork. There is a strong focus on helping the students maximize the opportunity they have. As a clinical staff member, I receive ample time and funds for continuing education.
cons: As the school budget gets tighter, there is more emphasis on being productive. The flow can get overwhelmed during certain times of the year, leading to more stressful days.

review_title: Good graduate student experience in chemical and biological engineering
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Boulder is a great place to live.  The research and research facilities are top-notch.  There is more of an emphasis on a work-life balance here than at other graduate programs.  The graduate student community is supportive and social, not competitive.
cons: There are not a lot of job prospects for PhDs in the area and there isn't much emphasis on industry recruiting PhDs.

review_title: Humanities grad students get the short end of the stick
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Being a TA often didn't take up a full 20 hours per week, as the position is set up to be. Most departments offer a health insurance waiver as well that makes health care very affordable, and Wardenburg is great.
cons: In my humanities department we were being paid far less than graduate TAs in other departments for teaching up to 75 students per semester.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Boulder is a pretty cool town with nice outdoor activities. Just don't expect a lot of diversity. As a graduate student, you get to spend five or more years of focused research on a specific topic. Be thankful you're not in the real world yet.
cons: As a graduate student, you get to spend five or more years of focused research on a specific topic. Be sure to be passionate about it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: CU is conveniently located in the beautiful city of Boulder, close to national parks and Denver; helpful and friendly staff, laid back atmosphere, sensible health insurance policy.
cons: Housing in the city of Boulder is expensive and prices keep rising; as in every graduate school, your work environment strongly depends on who is your adviser; as a graduate student, you don't have much benefits aside of some pretty basic ones.

pros: I loved being able to do the work that I had always dreamed of; Linguistics! It was really incredible to be working on a project that could be doing so much good in the future of the health industry and furthering machine learning in general.
cons: Honestly, it was an incredible opportunity and I have no cons to offer. You can choose your own hours and work as much as you want!

review_title: Great mission, interesting work, fascinating people
pros: If you like an academic environment with smart people, interesting problems, and a fantastic quality of life, CU is the place.
cons: Typical academic environment means things move very slowly. Lack of structure and accountability often inhibits problem solving. People conflicts tend to fester. Top administration is so focused on fund raising that they don't attend to real institution building.

pros: I worked at CU for ten years. First six years was a temp. through Bolder Staffing and the last four was a classified full time employee for the University.
cons: Very tough to get promoted to a better position as I was the best first responder they had in eight years and that is why promoting me was not an option for me

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Boulder, CO
pros:
- Very competitive salaries.
- Very good health insurance and benefits even for foreigners.
- A lot of help for international scholars and students in matters of immigration and taxation.
- Very supportive research environment.
- Very knowledgeable and supportive administrative staff.
- Great research, housing, teaching and recreation facilities.
- Close to the mountains and to Denver.
cons:
- There is not a clear promotion path for non-teaching faculty.
- Engineering centre is reaching its capacity.

review_title: It has been a pleasant experience
pros: The weather, the mountains, the outdoor sports, the great research opportunities, the great teaching staff and the friendly and approachable  people.
cons: The university of Colorado at Boulder isnt as well known in the many companies and that makes getting a job much harder.

pros: I worked multiple jobs during my time there. The best group to join is facilities management. This is Custodial, HR, Fire Management, Planning & Architecture. They are very diverse and the people are always so welcoming. They have picnics every year and a development program for young professionals.
cons: I graduated couldn't keep working there because I had to move. However working for the university is great. Unlimited careers and options.

review_title: A very friendly work environment. An amazing boss and a caring community.
job_title: IT ASSISTANT in University of Colorado, CO
pros: Learned a lot on the job. There were always assignments that I had to research for. I thrive off of learning new things and getting my feet wet and this job did that for me.
cons: I would've liked it if the job was a little more related to my graduate studies. Would have absolutely loved more programming assignments.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boulder, CO
pros: CU Boulder provides employees with great benefits and resources. The staff and faculty are friendly. An overall great place to work.
cons: Not too many cons working at CU Boulder. The main thing would be the amount of time it takes to process paperwork and follow through with HR related matters.

pros: I loved MCDB department, with some exceptions :). Most researchers are very supportive of each other. It is not uncommon for labs to share equipment, although this could be a pain sometimes :)
cons: At least for my position, salary was pretty low. But then it also depends on the lab you end up in. Mine was pretty modest when it comes to salaries of any employee/

job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Boulder, CO
pros: as a student, you get a lot of support and they know you need time to work on homework and projects so you will most likely not be overtaxing yourself in terms of how much work you're doing. people are super nice and depending on where you're working if it's related to what you're studying it's helpful.
cons: probably not learning a crazy amount if directly related to your field

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Boulder, CO
pros: Good benefits, pretty flexible hours and scheduling capabilities, the work is easy and mindless (in admissions operations office on East Campus)
cons: Not great pay, work slows all the time (often nothing to do)

pros: The TA program saved my life in grad school. Paid my tuition plus a chunk of my living expenses. I think it would all depend on the department and the professor, but I had a good experience.
cons: The pay was fairly low, and I wish I could have continued being a TA for my full time at school. But other than that I was pretty satisfied.

review_title: System administrator Avaya and training Cisco
pros:
Beautiful area
great people
great job
wonderful learning environment
and lifetime friends
cons: If I could find one it would be that contract positions are trial periods otherwise i truly enjoyed my experience.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Boulder, CO
pros: Convenient. Many different buses go to campus. Pay is acceptable if you include the scholarship money. Restaurants in town are very good.
cons: Undergrads are whiners: they constantly complain and email for no reason. No parking. No support from other instructors, professors, or staff.

pros: Benefits are outstanding. People are very friendly and helpful. Had opportunity to work remotely twice a week.
cons:
Too bureaucratic. Too many road blocks to getting anything done. Division of labor too well defined. There was plenty of work to do, but needing to wait on understaffed departments prevented work from being done on a timely matter.
Too many unnecessary meetings.

pros: Flexible working hours, good support from professor, looks good on resume, satisfaction of helping students learn an advanced topic
cons: Poor salary, no benefits, pay is capped at a certain number of hours even though in reality you need to work a lot more than those hours.  This is not a job you take for the money, it's a job you take for the resume.

review_title: Great employer - lots of learning and growth opportunities
pros: You will work with some very smart, motivated people. There is a lot to learn about higher education, and there are many challenges to learn from. Lastly, the benefits are great.
cons: It takes a while for changes to be proposed, reviewed, and implemented. There's a lot of bureaucracy, but that is the nature of higher education!

review_title: A once strong ship now sinking fast!
pros: A sense of scientific community. Investigators show good intent.
cons: No clear vision or innovation to maintain federal support. Investigators completely lack oversight and are unable to manage employees, even when significant problems arise. Expectations are never clear and favoritism runs rampant.

pros: The people are great to work with, depending on what department you work in. The planetarium and Comm department were especially pleasant to work in.
cons: The pay is severely below the market rate. I do not know the reason, but for some reason the designation (undergraduate student, graduate student, or full-time) primarily determines the pay level, despite doing exactly the same work.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boulder, CO
pros: Great personal network, caring co-workers and supervisors, great work environment and culture.
cons: Constantly increasing mandatory PERA (pension retirement plan) contributions, freeze on pay increases, and constant benefit cost increases.

review_title: Excellent place to work for CU Boulder students!
job_title: Student Assistant II in University of Colorado, CO
pros:
- Staff members are very understanding of students' busy schedules
- Flexible hours
- Team environment
- Really nice offices
cons:
- As with many part-time student positions, pay increases are based on time elapsed and not necessarily on merit.
- Would have appreciated more opportunity to work more closely with staff members on relevant projects instead of simple data entry

pros: Other co-workers, student employees, atmosphere of campus, great location
cons: Tense racial climate, navigating politics, many of the directors of departments are disconnected from entry-level employees, lack of support for staff/faculty of color and from other underrepresented groups

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Boulder, CO
pros: Exceptional leaders in the field and state-of-the-art facilities. Supportive work environment and plenty of opportunities to explore and relax outside of the lab.
cons: Boulder is an expensive city to live in. Finding good childcare can be a hassle here. Can also be an adjustment for people with moderate or conservative political views, as the city is uber liberal in character.

pros: Great environment for research and teaching, large national labs presence and robust tech presence creates opportunities for collaboration and entrepreneurship.
cons: The state tax regulations (TABOR) limit funding for higher-ed, making CU-Boulder more dependent on tuition revenue. This has some perverse incentives at times and has (at least in Computer Science) led to very large class sizes and resource limitations.

review_title: Housing and Dining is a decent job option for students
pros:
Free meal every shift
Free coffee
You get to listen to your own music if you are working in a shop
On campus location makes it easy to go to work from class or home
Management understands scheduling around classes
cons:
Standing for long periods
Responsibility for getting shifts covered for tests or sick days gets put on the student

pros: Positive environment, good benefits, feel like you are making a difference in the lives of young people, great work/life balance, opportunities to learn.
cons: Higher ed. experiencing financial instability in time of Covid and after years of budget cuts from state and federal level so uncertain about the long-term prospects. Guessing furlough pay cuts that were temporary will be come permanent.

review_title: Good place to work and a world class university.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Amazing location. Lots of great resources. Excellent scientific laboratories in town for collaborations. Decent pay for graduate students.
cons: Reducing funding in many situations is a challenge. Very strict parking and university standards. Some buildings need a major upgrade in technology or infrastructure. Some classes are antiquated in ideas.

job_title: Research Assistant (PhD Student) in Boulder, CO
pros: Very high quality professors and administrative staff (I can only speak of the Mechanical Engineering Department).
cons: They pay and benefits for Ph.D. students are better than some other locations, however still lower than I think they should be.  There is always more work to do, and an expectation for you to do more work than you probably should be doing.

job_title: Research Assistant (PhD Student) in Boulder, CO
pros: The atmosphere of the department can't be beat--other students are intelligent, passionate about their research, but there is little to no competition among students. Professors are very friendly and world class. And Boulder is an awesome town to be a graduate student in!
cons: The stipend can vary widely depending on the department and even within the department, depending on the adviser.

pros: Some departments are very encouraging of diversity in thought and class instruction. Lovely campus with great coffee shops. No overt racism, crime is very low.
cons: You tend to work way beyond your hours if you are teaching and will not be compensated for the overtime. Some departments are mired in cultural conflict and bureaucratic battles and take the students down with them.

pros: Flexible with a student schedule and a super friendly work environment. Everyone is genuinely interested in helping each other and the students and families that come in needing direction.
cons: They can't offer anything more than part time.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Lots of opportunities to pursue research of interest, flexible hours, easy commuting and good perks, Good mentorship opportunities with senior level advisors
cons: CU is a large academic institution that suffers from most of the trappings that large organizations like this do which include politics, not easy to advance, difficult to increase compensation.

pros: Being a student, it's very convenient to work in an office on campus. They work with your schedule really well, and are very progressive; always moving on to the new thing.
cons: Your experience completely depends on your department and who manages it, so go to try to get into another office if you don't like yours

pros: Working for CU is great. The pay and benefits are good, and the management (in my department at least) is amazing. Also, Boulder is a beautiful city, with a great community.
cons: CU is a very big organization, so there's sometimes a disconnect between the higher ups and the lowly employees. But it's not that bad, and it's getting better.

pros: Working on the grounds crew at CU was a great experience with a good team and supervisors
cons: Sometimes the management was a little too relaxed and some team members lacked motivation.

pros: postdoctoral fellows are given great benefits--retirement, medical, dental
cons: your experience is completely contingent upon who you work for and their lab policies--no cohesive HR team, no rules as to how postdocs are allowed to be compensated/ treated etc.

pros: it was so much fun, it was trendy, young, youthful. lots of career opportunities and lots of areas to continue to grow.
cons: honestly, not that many. it's low pay because its a public school. but other than that, sometimes people stay in jobs for a long time but that's not really a con.

review_title: Worth the pay, but lousy management.
pros: Good room and board and some relative freedom compared to other RA jobs.
cons: Those in charge are pretty incompetent, and do not value your time.

job_title: Chief of Police in Boulder, CO
pros: Great benefits, access to resources, very involved faculty. Commute is ok if u can afford Boulder. Nice campus, educated people to work with
cons: Demanding hours.  Lots of competing demands. Lack of stability within HR AND AT THE TOP.  People starving for some fore thought to where we are headed.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Employers are happy to work around students' schedules because they understand school comes first. Pay is usually competitive. Everyone in my office was very friendly.
cons: Not very many opportunities to raise your pay. Being a student employee can make you feel detached from the rest of the office. Work can get a little boring.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Denver, CO
pros: Flexible 8-5 job. Lovely environment, and coworkers understand when you need to take time off for other things on a weekday.
cons: Pay is low. I have learned so much here, but my department pays pretty low. It makes it hard sometimes.

review_title: Overalll, a good place, but not without it's limitations
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boulder, CO
pros: Everyone is on a first name basis. Job security. Academic environment. Beautiful campus and surroundings. Boulder is a great place to work. Always something going on in or around campus.
cons: Not a lot of job growth or movement. Lots of bureaucratic tape. Lots of office politics. Outdated technology and outdated thinking.

pros: The university offered a good range of classes to students and had quite a bit of flexibility to take classes outside of the department.
cons: Due to having a higher opinion of research activities than education, some of the professors were awful educators and I would not recommend this university to students not looking for research-based degrees

pros: Around football, good sports experience . Even if you end up not working in sports you get good real world experience.
cons: A lot of hours, more demanding than most jobs. You do a lot less with film than you’d expect. A lot more administrative stuff.

review_title: Graduate student in chemistry and biochemistry.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: The Chemistry and Biochemistry department has many distinguished faculty.  Boulder is a great place to live and the campus is beautiful.
cons: The department is very disorganized and the adminsitration is not good a clearly outlining what is required for each student.  The med insurance is only 70% covered by the department.

review_title: I worked for the Institute of Cognitive Science for about a year as a Treebank/UMLS annotator.
pros: Hours are completely flexible, work can be done remotely if you have a laptop. Colleagues are friendly and helpful. Also more.
cons: There really is very little overarching structure or oversight. The pay is not particularly competitive. The work can be repetitive and boring.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Tuition waiver, graduate students and professors are professional, culture and atmosphere, location and after hours activities are really nice, equipment and funding are good
cons: The professors can be old and outdated, teaching obsolete concepts and techniques, the weather is not as nice as advertised.

review_title: Linux System Administration as a student employee at a University
job_title: Student Systems Administrator in Boulder, CO
pros: The workplace atmosphere is relaxed with little corporate stress. But this is all relative as a student employee. Boulder is a great city to live and work in.
cons: Univeristy and state politics interfere with productivity occasionally. Pay to responisibility ratio is low even for a student.

job_title: Community Assistant in University of Colorado, CO
pros: Since my coworkers are all around my age, it's fun at times. And work-study isn't hard at all.
cons: The pay is JUST above minimum-wage, even with graveyard shifts. You live paycheck to paycheck.

pros: Excellent benefits and colleagues. Most people I work with are quite intelligent; whether it's a professor or secretary.
cons: Because this is such a large organization, it can be frustrating because it can feel like unless you're administrator or a tenured faculty member, you don't have a lot of say in what decisions are made.

pros: Everyone I worked with was incredibly accepting and kind. It was obvious that my colleagues were very passionate about the work they did, especially in improving experiences for students.
cons: Sometimes work needed to go through/get approved by different levels in administration so it was not completed as efficiently as it could have been.

review_title: Great place to work for students
job_title: Digital Imaging Specialist in Boulder, CO
pros: This is a great place to work at if you're a student looking for something to get your mind off of academics. The hours are super flexible and its a good working environment
cons: The lab gets chilly at times since its at 68 degree's Fahrenheit and the job gets VERY repetitive.

review_title: Flexible hours help while attending classes.
pros: Had the opportunity to get to know my professors while still helping the department.  Flexible hours made getting school work done a possibility.
cons: At times, the work given to do required more access than I was afforded as a student and it could be hard to complete the assigned tasks.

pros: Get to work with amazing people in a beautiful city on an amazing campus. Lots of available resources. Opportunity to work with other scientists from other organizations and community outreach.
cons: As is common in this field the pay is not that great but most people are not there for pay.

review_title: Engineering center - Great place to do R&D
pros: Very motivating, rewarding, beautiful place, full of smart professors and students. The engineering school is top class in the country. Great research is going on in many areas.
cons: Minor things: sometimes too much to do, everyone is very busy and stressed during finals. Overalll not many cons,

review_title: Tutor- Mentor at the Academic Success and Achievement Program
job_title: ASAP Tutor- Mentor in Boulder, CO
pros: Best working hours suited to my schedule and flexibility to choose subjects of my choice to teach and complimentary tutor training sessions
cons: Very strict punch in and punch out policies with very little wiggle room which is actually beneficial for ASAP but sometimes becomes very demanding

job_title: Coordinator of Operations in Boulder, CO
pros: CU Boulder has a community feel - every employee at every level is vital to the mission and is treated as such.  There are excellent benefits that go beyond insurance and PTO.
cons: Working in Higher Education at a state institution is limiting financially, so if you want to make money, choose somewhere else.

pros: Good benefits and good work life balance.
cons: Inequity between PTO for CU staff and classified staff, difficult to navigate the bureaucracy, often a hostile work environment with difficult to work with people.

pros: I am a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado at Boulder. My job is in a fantastic location, it has very flexible hours and I work with smart, like-minded people.
cons: Postdocs do not make much money and it is hard to define your role in the academic world.

pros: Great benefits including double match on 401a plan (after a year) and good health insurance options. Many knowledgeable faculty in the department that I worked in (chemistry).
cons: Lower pay than in an industry or national lab postdoc. In my particular group, there wasn't always funding to purchase equipment that I needed.

review_title: I taught students, met with them individually and had terrific classes in both Ethnic  Studies and Creative Writing.
pros: The students were intelligent. The people I worked with were kind and friendly. It was always a joy to go to work.
cons: Sometimes the working time became too difficult.

review_title: Lots of variety within the University.  Experience depends on who you work with/for.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Beautiful location.  Nice campus.  Lots of great things available to you: gym, hospital, career services, etc.  Access to lots of prestigious researchers.
cons: Disorganized and bureaucratic.  Graduate Student Stipend is very low considering cost of living in Boulder.

pros: The hours can be very flexible, the supervisors in each department are hardworking and great to work with.
cons: The wage was low and the opportunities for salary increase were low as well. After a couple semesters, you might want to ask to change department or responsibilities just to keep the job fresh.

review_title: Great on campus job for during the school year.
job_title: Weight Room Attendant in Boulder, CO
pros: Very flexible schedules, great work environment, only students work this job, great management, learn from trainers, be more knowledgeable about weight lifting.
cons: Could be boring and dull because of the repetition of work that has to be done, not a lot of benefits.

pros: Young people are always around. Eco pass included, lots of educational growth opportunities. Nice place to be, beautiful campus.
cons:
Construction happens all the time and access to key roads and routes is changed without much notice.
Always the promise of impending budget cuts as the upper management gets more money.

pros:
Competitive salary and benefits for graduate student positions
Standard departmental support available for resources necessary
Some departments have good secretaries to help you so you don't have to deal with the bureaucratic nightmare happening behind the scene
cons:
Equipments and some facilities could be outdated depending on the department
Exit support is relatively lacking

pros: Intelligent folks to work with, ability to pursue what you want to work on, casual atmosphere, great location (Boulder) with lots to do.
cons:
Boulder is a very expensive place to live - but this is not the University's fault!
If you are a researcher, you depend on grants.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Excellent dedication to research on all levels, friendly and professional advisers, and wonderful city to work in.
cons: Disorganized office staff, old building facilities, and unclear graduate student payment each year.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Smart, motivated co workers, freedom to pursue personal development, Good programs to transition IP to industry, competitive lab space
cons: Building was like a dungeon, very depressing to work in a place with no windows. Salary and benefits as an employee of a government institution could be better

job_title: Research Associate in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Nice place to work. Staff and management very friendly. Lots of extracurricular activities to do. Funding available in terms of fellowships. Good mix of male and female population. Lots of outdoor activities
cons: Not very good in terms of benefits. University should provide health insurance

pros: Work with your schedule. Didn't have to work nights or weekends. The people I worked with were amazing. I learned a lot working what I did.
cons: I can't really think of any cons. They were really accommodating and worked around my schedule.

review_title: Staff at the University are very supportive of growth and my overall experience has been positive.
pros:
Health Insurance benefits
Great pay
Tuition remission
Flexibility and openness to adjust work schedules
cons: Some communication could be improved in training new employees and introducing them to their benefit package.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Perform novel research that makes the world a better place.
cons: You work long hours for little to no pay.

pros: Diversity of people, diversity of jobs available, learn spanish! amicable management.
cons: low pay, silly almost worthless management just like any profession

review_title: Nice research assistant experience in University of Colorado
pros: Good environment. Great location. Good balance between work and personal life. Close to mountains and you can ski in the winter
cons: Slow pace working environment. Little support from the school for the engineering department. Often require help from others in Physics department.

review_title: Great university in a great location
pros: Location - boulder is nice, faculty is top notch, rec center is state of the art
cons: Winters are harsh, too far from a big city

pros:
Overall, CU is a great place to work. 
Office culture is casual. 
Managers encouraged professional and personal growth. 
The tuition benefit is outstanding. 
Very flexible with time-off (sick or vacation). The work/life balance was very good.
cons: Universities pay much lower than comparable jobs in the private sector.

job_title: Teaching Assistant, Course Assistant, and Undergraduate Researcher in Boulder, CO
pros: The university has afforded me with opportunities to expand my interests within academia. They pay on time and consistently. The wages are as expected for undergraduate work.
cons: There are maximum hours placed as limitation and hours worked from home are not counted, although I've never insisted on it.

pros: Nice environment and close to a lot of top notch national laboratories
cons: management are not good in general.  promotion is limited.

job_title: Study Abroad Advisor in Boulder, CO
pros: Fun and energetic place to work and be a part of.
cons: I really don't have anything bad to say about working for the University of Colorado. I wish there would have been a permanent job opening while I was working in the office!

pros: Great Benefits, good people, higher ed
cons: Very little in the way of professional development tracks, many long term employees punching the clock until retirement

pros: i love pros and cons
cons: same thing now i need this research to do my work so please stop asking me questions

pros: Worked in IT/Telecommunications graduate lab with 7/24 access to utilzed equipment and gain real world knowledge.
cons: As a graduate student you are limited to only 20 hours of work per week.  Living on less than $1100 per month gets old.

review_title: Fun, fast-paced, hands-on projects in an amazing geographic location
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, beautiful city, flexible graduate student life, getting a valuable degree.
cons: Low pay, work can stack up suddenly, need to manage your own time

review_title: fantastic support within department despite low wage
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros:
fantastic support within department from excellent faculty and faculty support
strong intellectual environment amongst faculty, peers, and students
campus is gorgeous year round
cons:
salary and hours are non-negotiable
expensive fees for students
very low diversity at all levels of school

review_title: Benefits are great, things happen slowly
pros: As a public university, CU has great health benefits among others.
cons: The pay isn't incredible which is understandable given it is an educational institution. Boulder's amazing location makes up for it; however, it's hard to afford living in Boulder as an employee.

review_title: Great Benefits, difficult place to work
job_title: Athletic Equipment Manager in Boulder, CO
pros:
Great Benefits.
Unique environment.
Great travel opportunities. 
Access to great athletics
cons:
No support from administration. 
Departments are unwilling to work with each other.
Emotionally strenuous. 
EXTREMELY UNDERPAID. 60-70 hour weeks minimum and most weekends.

pros: Even as a graduate student in the CS department I had an enormous amount of freedom in teaching.
cons: Pay isn't great unless you can get two sections of the class you are teaching. There is very little support.

review_title: Fantastic location, excellent research, poor management
pros: Top research university at a fantastic location and great campus. Many opportunities to interact with excellent scientists. Many high-tech companies are located in this area.
cons: Salaries are low, poor management decisions, work load can be extremely heavy, lack of incentives.

job_title: Student Systems Administrator in London, England
pros: It is a great place to work.Office space was big and people were friendly.Completely paid for my tuition too.
cons: Nothing that I could think of.It is a great place to work.Office space was big and people were friendly
